articles.headline: Yahoo Woos a Social Networking Site
articles.snippet: Yahoo has offered about $900 million to woo Mark Zuckerberg, the 22-year-old founder of the popular social networking site Facebook.com.
articles.abstract: Yahoo has offered about $900 million to woo Mark Zuckerberg, the 22-year-old founder of the popular social networking site Facebook.com.
articles.lead_paragraph: Mark Zuckerberg is a member of the Google generation, one too young to remember all the ambitions dashed and fortunes lost when the last dot-com boom ended.

articles.headline: Time to Bring Share Lending Into the Light
articles.snippet: If the S.E.C. continues to require that shares be borrowed before they can be shorted, then an effort to make the stock loan market more transparent makes sense.
articles.abstract: If the S.E.C. continues to require that shares be borrowed before they can be shorted, then an effort to make the stock loan market more transparent makes sense.
articles.lead_paragraph: He who sells what isn’t his’n

articles.headline: Luring Customers From Medicare
articles.snippet: Critics see the flourishing trend of fee-for-service health plans as further evidence that the government is paying private industry to take Medicare off its hands.
articles.abstract: Critics see the flourishing trend of fee-for-service health plans as further evidence that the government is paying private industry to take Medicare off its hands.
articles.lead_paragraph: For years, private insurers have offered alternatives to the federal Medicare program that are meant to give patients lower-cost options than the government coverage provides. More than 7 million people now subscribe to such plans, out of a total Medicare population of 42.5 million.

articles.headline: Tribune to Consider Sale of Some Media Assets
articles.snippet: The company said it would investigate whether to sell any or all of its 11 newspapers and 25 television stations.
articles.abstract: The company said it would investigate whether to sell any or all of its 11 newspapers and 25 television stations.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Tribune Company said last night that it would consider selling any or all of its 11 newspapers and 25 television stations, a move that could reshape the media landscape. The properties include The Los Angeles Times, The Chicago Tribune and The Baltimore Sun.

articles.headline: Focus Turns to the Chief of H.P.; Stock Falls
articles.snippet: Pressure is mounting on Hewlett-Packard’s chief to explain his role in the company’s spying operation after his name figured in new documents in the investigation.
articles.abstract: Pressure is mounting on Hewlett-Packard’s chief to explain his role in the company’s spying operation after his name figured in new documents in the investigation.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 21 — Pressure is mounting on Hewlett-Packard’s chief executive, Mark V. Hurd, to explain what appears to have been a greater role in the company’s spying operation than was initially indicated.
articles.byline: By Damon Darlin and Matt Richtel

articles.headline: In China, Children of the Rich Learn Class, Minus the Struggle
articles.snippet: In China, affluent parents are planning ways to cement their children’s place in a fast-emerging elite.
articles.abstract: In China, affluent parents are planning ways to cement their children’s place in a fast-emerging elite.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI, Sept. 21 — Every weekday this summer, Rose Lei drove her daughter, Angelina, 5, to a golf complex at the edge of central Shanghai for a two-hour, $200 individual lesson with a teaching pro from Scotland.

articles.headline: Strained, Army Looks to Guard for More Relief
articles.snippet: Army officials say they may be forced to make greater use of the National Guard to provide enough troops for overseas deployments.
articles.abstract: Army officials say they may be forced to make greater use of the National Guard to provide enough troops for overseas deployments.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 — Strains on the Army from the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan have become so severe that Army officials say they may be forced to make greater use of the National Guard to provide enough troops for overseas deployments.
articles.byline: By Thom Shanker and Michael R. Gordon

articles.headline: Luring Customers From Medicare
articles.snippet: For years, private insurers have offered alternatives to the federal Medicare program that are meant to give patients lower-cost options than the government coverage provides. More than 7 million people now subscribe to such plans, out of a total ...
articles.abstract: For years, private insurers have offered alternatives to the federal Medicare program that are meant to give patients lower-cost options than the government coverage provides. More than 7 million people now subscribe to such plans, out of a total Medicare population of 42.5 million.      But suddenly a type of private insurance plan is gaining ground that looks very similar to the basic coverage long available to anyone with a federally issued Medicare card.
articles.lead_paragraph: For years, private insurers have offered alternatives to the federal Medicare program that are meant to give patients lower-cost options than the government coverage provides. More than 7 million people now subscribe to such plans, out of a total Medicare population of 42.5 million.

articles.headline: U.S. Urges H.I.V. Tests for Adults and Teenagers
articles.snippet: In a major shift of policy, the federal government recommended yesterday that all teenagers and most adults have H.I.V. tests as part of routine medical care because too many Americans infected with the AIDS virus don't know it.     The recommenda...
articles.abstract: In a major shift of policy, the federal government recommended yesterday that all teenagers and most adults have H.I.V. tests as part of routine medical care because too many Americans infected with the AIDS virus don't know it.     The recommendation, by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, urges testing at least once for everyone aged 13 to 64 and annual tests for those with high-risk behavior.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a major shift of policy, the federal government recommended yesterday that all teenagers and most adults have H.I.V. tests as part of routine medical care because too many Americans infected with the AIDS virus don't know it.

articles.headline: Tribune to Consider Sale of Some Media Assets
articles.snippet: The Tribune Company said last night that it would consider selling any or all of its 11 newspapers and 25 television stations, a move that could reshape the media landscape. The properties include The Los Angeles Times, The Chicago Tribune and The...
articles.abstract: The Tribune Company said last night that it would consider selling any or all of its 11 newspapers and 25 television stations, a move that could reshape the media landscape. The properties include The Los Angeles Times, The Chicago Tribune and The Baltimore Sun.     The announcement came yesterday after the board approved an agreement between the company and the Chandler family, its largest shareholder.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Tribune Company said last night that it would consider selling any or all of its 11 newspapers and 25 television stations, a move that could reshape the media landscape. The properties include The Los Angeles Times, The Chicago Tribune and The Baltimore Sun.

articles.headline: Yahoo Woos a Social Networking Site
articles.snippet: Mark Zuckerberg is a member of the Google generation, one too young to remember all the ambitions dashed and fortunes lost when the last dot-com boom ended.     That may be one reason Mr. Zuckerberg, the 22-year-old founder of Facebook, a social n...
articles.abstract: Mark Zuckerberg is a member of the Google generation, one too young to remember all the ambitions dashed and fortunes lost when the last dot-com boom ended.     That may be one reason Mr. Zuckerberg, the 22-year-old founder of Facebook, a social networking Web site, has so far shied away from selling his company, rejecting offers that would have made him several hundred million dollars.
articles.lead_paragraph: Mark Zuckerberg is a member of the Google generation, one too young to remember all the ambitions dashed and fortunes lost when the last dot-com boom ended.

articles.headline: Strained, Army Looks to Guard for More Relief
articles.snippet: Strains on the Army from the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan have become so severe that Army officials say they may be forced to make greater use of the National Guard to provide enough troops for overseas deployments.     Senior Army officers have d...
articles.abstract: Strains on the Army from the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan have become so severe that Army officials say they may be forced to make greater use of the National Guard to provide enough troops for overseas deployments.     Senior Army officers have discussed that analysis -- and described the possible need to use more members of the National Guard -- with Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld's senior adviser on personnel, David S. C. Chu, according to Pentagon officials.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 - Strains on the Army from the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan have become so severe that Army officials say they may be forced to make greater use of the National Guard to provide enough troops for overseas deployments.
articles.byline: By Thom Shanker and Michael R. Gordon

articles.headline: Focus Turns to the Chief of H.P.; Stock Falls
articles.snippet: Pressure is mounting on Hewlett-Packard's chief executive, Mark V. Hurd, to explain what appears to have been a greater role in the company's spying operation than was initially indicated.      Mr. Hurd has largely escaped mention in connection wi...
articles.abstract: Pressure is mounting on Hewlett-Packard's chief executive, Mark V. Hurd, to explain what appears to have been a greater role in the company's spying operation than was initially indicated.      Mr. Hurd has largely escaped mention in connection with the company's efforts to obtain private phone records and otherwise trace leaks from its board. But on Thursday, after his name figured in documents newly appearing in the investigation, Hewlett-Packard's stock price fell significantly for the first time since the revelations began early this month. The shares closed down 5.19 percent, at $34.87.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 21 - Pressure is mounting on Hewlett-Packard's chief executive, Mark V. Hurd, to explain what appears to have been a greater role in the company's spying operation than was initially indicated.
articles.byline: By Damon Darlin and Matt Richtel

articles.headline: TOP REPUBLICANS REACH AN ACCORD ON DETAINEE BILL
articles.snippet: The Bush administration and Congressional Republicans reached agreement Thursday on legislation governing the treatment and interrogation of terrorism suspects after weeks of debate that divided Republicans heading into the midterm elections.     ...
articles.abstract: The Bush administration and Congressional Republicans reached agreement Thursday on legislation governing the treatment and interrogation of terrorism suspects after weeks of debate that divided Republicans heading into the midterm elections.     Under the deal, President Bush dropped his demand that Congress redefine the nation's obligations under the Geneva Conventions, handing a victory to a group of Republicans, including Senator John McCain of Arizona, whose opposition had created a showdown over a fundamental aspect of the rules for battling terrorism.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 - The Bush administration and Congressional Republicans reached agreement Thursday on legislation governing the treatment and interrogation of terrorism suspects after weeks of debate that divided Republicans heading into the midterm elections.

articles.headline: Time to Bring Share Lending Into the Light
articles.snippet: He who sells what isn't his'n  must buy it back or go to pris'n.  -- Attributed to Daniel Drew, 1797-1879       The annals of short selling have no better exemplar than Daniel Drew, whose career demonstrated both the risks and rewards of pursuing ...
articles.abstract: He who sells what isn't his'n  must buy it back or go to pris'n.  -- Attributed to Daniel Drew, 1797-1879       The annals of short selling have no better exemplar than Daniel Drew, whose career demonstrated both the risks and rewards of pursuing such an unpopular strategy. He made, and lost, several fortunes, along the way founding a Methodist seminary that bears his name. He died broke.
articles.lead_paragraph: He who sells what isn't his'n must buy it back or go to pris'n. -- Attributed to Daniel Drew, 1797-1879

articles.headline: Pickers Are Few, and Growers Blame Congress
articles.snippet: The pear growers here in Lake County waited decades for a crop of shapely fruit like the one that adorned their orchards last month.      ''I felt like I went to heaven,'' said Nick Ivicevich, recalling the perfection of his most abundant crop in ...
articles.abstract: The pear growers here in Lake County waited decades for a crop of shapely fruit like the one that adorned their orchards last month.      ''I felt like I went to heaven,'' said Nick Ivicevich, recalling the perfection of his most abundant crop in 45 years of tending trees.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAKEPORT, Calif. - The pear growers here in Lake County waited decades for a crop of shapely fruit like the one that adorned their orchards last month.
